Award.AwardTitle: Dynamic and Fatigue Analysis of Healthy and Diseased Red Blood Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Red blood cells experience a tremendous amount of shearing, stretching and bending as they circulate through the body. Progressive damage occurs in the circulating cells before they are removed and replaced with new ones. Much of the research on cellular biomechanics focuses on a single application of load, which does not reproduce the dynamic repetitive loading that the cells experience in the body. This research will use a new microfluidic tool to apply repetitive cell loading to create a fundamental understanding of the mechanical origins of damage in circulating red blood cells. The results will provide quantitative links between cellular biomechanics and cell biology, thus advancing our understanding of the significantly shortened lifespan of transfused red blood cells and those made abnormal by diseases. The multidisciplinary approach will broaden participation of underrepresented groups in Science and Engineering. The PI is placing special emphasis on encouraging women students to participate research at the interface of engineering and life sciences.

The objective of this research is to establish the fundamental correlations between the cellular dynamic and fatigue properties, the in vivo circulation history and influences from pathophysiological factors in human red blood cells. This work specifically addresses questions: (a) how to implement the dynamic viscoelasticity and fatigue measurements of individual cells at a relatively high throughput, and (b) how to quantify the pathophysiological influences on cellular biomechanics. This research will develop an experimental strategy for dynamic and fatigue measurement of single cells, by integrating knowledge and techniques of microfluidics, alternating current electrokinetics, digital modulation and biomechanics. The damage process in cell membranes caused by the mechanical forces in circulation is significantly analogous to material fatigue. Experimentally determined Wöhler curves in combination with Miner's rule will be used for remaining life prediction in red blood cells influenced by in vivo aging and sickle cell disease. Novelty of this research lies in the new experimental strategy and a new perspective in cellular biomechanics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Red blood cell (RBC) consists mainly hemoglobin, which is covered by a membrane composed of lipids and proteins. RBCs are subjected to repeated passive deformation when they move through the circulatory system. During this process, RBCs progressively lose their membrane integrity, become rigid, and breakdown for production of new ones in the bone marrow. In diseases, such as anemias, the membrane integrity and cell mechanical properties are not only adversely affected but the process of membrane failure becomes accelerated. As the membrane is the only structural component supporting the cell’s mechanical stability, it is of great importance to study the mechanical fatigue of cell membranes, namely the degradation and damage in cell membranes when RBCs are under cyclic straining, mimicking the episodes of forces in blood circulation. Previous studies have been focused on cell deformability and rheology measured from a single application of stress and force or in a shear flow condition in capillary like structures.

This project established a general method for the study of fatigue behavior in biological cells, with the capability demonstrated using human RBCs in health and sickle cell disease. The corresponding theoretical and numerical modeling methods for extraction of the material properties of cell membranes from experimental measurements of cell deformation are reported in our publications. The project provides necessary foundation which can be further developed by incorporating gas environment control for measurement of accumulated degradation in cell membranes due to the coupled oxidative and shear stressing, mimicking that exerted on RBCs when they move in different locations of the cardiovascular system. Results from this project suggested a new direction, fatigue for research in cell biomechanics and shed light on how to relate the role of mechanical fatigue influencing cellular biophysical properties.

The educational activities of this project promoted the professional development and training of several graduate and undergraduate students. These students were trained to design and fabricate microfluidics devices, characterize material properties of biological cells, perform analytical and numerical analyses, analyze and present research data, write research papers, and present at professional conferences. Two graduate students have been supported. They graduated and acquired their PhD degrees through participation in the research in this project. The techniques and methods have also been incorporated into the undergraduate and graduate courses taught by the principal investigator.

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2020
Modified by: E Du
